title: For the true aficionado
body:
This device surely represents a new level in portable espresso creation. What a massive innovation over the previous model, the Nanopresso, which was already a very nifty little device. But this is something else. The Pico will create true espresso with luscious crema and a thick, viscous body. It will pull out all the those nuanced flavors from your blend. Judging just on the quality of the espresso, this device rivals my $2500 prosumer machine. Of course, the prosumer machine is superior for many other reasons, but quality and taste of the shot alone? They are nearly equals.

Here's how the Pico is different from the Nano and why it is capable of creating such good espresso:

1. A true espresso portafilter shower screen and basket, made from stainless steel and precisely machined.
3. beautiful, grippable metal portafilter. No more struggling to unscrew parts.
2. A robust, larger pump with smoother action and response, capable of generating more pressure and pushing out a larger flow of water.
3. Rubber seals and durable threads throughout. You'll never worry about water leaking or threads wearing down on the Pico.
4. The water tank is now integrated into the pump housing. This saved a lot of space and also further eliminates the possibility of hot water leaking out of the machine and burning you. The volume of the water tank is perfectly measured for a double shot of espresso.

One caveat: YOU NEED A GOOD GRINDER. This device, like any good espresso machine, requires precision coffee grinds of uniform coarseness. You will likely need to go finer than what you get from preground stuff like Illy or Lavazza. Invest in a good manual grinder, like 1Zpresso JX Pro or J-Max. They are amazing devices that will last your lifetime.

I'm not going to bother addressing any of the "problems" identified by negative reviews. If you are intrigued by the possibility of creating sublime espresso from a device that fits in the palm of your hand, and you understand and appreciate the artistry of pulling a great shot, this machine is for your you. If you just want some caffeine, don't bother.

Das Auspacken ist schon mal ein Erlebnis für sich. Wirklich hochwertig und professionell gemacht. Die Verarbeitungsqualität ist auch wirklich gut. Metall und Kunststoff.

Der Aufbau ist simpel, alles passt in die mitgelieferte kleine Tasche dank der ausgeklügelten ineinander stapelbaren Elemente.

Im Vorfeld habe ich mir einige Videos angeschaut. Das empfehle ich auch wirklich jedem. Denn die ersten Espressi werden nicht gut. Ich habe einige Zeit gebraucht um das Temperaturmanagement und den Richtigen Mahlgrad des Kaffees zu finden.

Die Espressowelt war für mich vollkommen neu, der Einstieg mit der Picopresso entsprechend etwas holprig. Als Kaffeemühle nutze ich die Timemore C2 mit einem Mahlgrad von 9 bei dem aktuellen Kaffee den ich nutze. Eine leichte bittere Note schwingt immer mit, aber mittlerweile klappt es auch mit der Crema.

Fazit: Die Picopresso ist wirklich gut. Ich nutze sie sowohl zuhause, also auch beim Camping in Holland. Mit ein wenig Zeit und Geduld wird der Kaffee, und such die Milchgetränke damit wirklich gut. Als Einstieg in die Kaffeewelt ist sie meiner Meinung nach aber nur bedingt geeignet. Für jemanden der sich aber ernsthaft dafür interessiert und die Zeit investieren will, lohnt es sich. Es wird stetig besser und man freut sich über neue Erfolge. Alles in allem wirklich empfehlenswert.

title: Travel Espresso for the Aficionado
body:
PURPOSE:
This product serves a niche but growing market: the espresso aficionado (such as myself) who doesn't want to give up life's simple luxuries while on the trail (I am an avid backpacker who doesn't mind the extra weight of a portable espresso machine+grinder+beans) or back home visiting the folks in a town where the "espresso" most coffee shops serve is either burnt-tasting, sour, or otherwise completely over-/under-extracted. Note: YOU WILL NEED PRACTICE AND PATIENCE TO DIAL IN YOUR SHOT.

FLAVOR:
This handy little gadget will absolutely NOT be replacing my Breville Barista Express (plus associated accessories) anytime soon, however it definitely (as mentioned above) can make much better espresso than is available when I am away from home. I prefer a ristretto (1:1 ratio) that comes out in 25-27s on my Barista Express but that is not possible with this considering the pressure/piston limitations on this device, so I have to settle for a slightly coarser grind setting and longer shot.

GRIND SETTING: I used it in conjunction with the 1Z-Presso K-Max manual grinder. If anyone else has this combo I recommend a grind setting of between 2.75-3.00 for an input of 18g medium-dark roasted beans (you're welcome - this took me many frustrating attempts to figure out).

BUILD QUALITY/USABILITY:
This thing seems to be built with very high quality materials - not as good as those of a $500+ home espresso machine but pretty close. Love that it comes with a case as well. Certain things are mildly-moderately frustrating but overall this thing is pretty well built:
- Piston mechanism digs into the hand a bit and is slightly difficult to balance the device over a cup while pressing as it requires quite a push once pressure has built up.
- O ring on the water reservoir side is a bit difficult to get back into place after removing.
- I cannot stress enough the two things that gave me the biggest headache while dialing in: DO NOT TAMP HARD OR GRIND TOO FINE. (Yes I know...hard to define what this really means..) More on this below..

TROUBLESHOOTING:
This is where I felt the need to dock a star (and if it weren't for the fact that there is no other device this portable that produces this level of espresso quality, I would probably have docked two). If you tamp too hard or grind too fine, the pressure required to extract will be too high and it will become near impossible to obtain your shot. The device will subsequently seize up, and you will have to wait 10-30 minutes for it to slowly release before you can unscrew the portafilter. This is NOT your typical home espresso machine, and the tamping should feel relatively very gentle (you may barely start to see the imprint of the rings in the puck). As they note in the manual, you keep the dosing funnel on while tamping. Even with the funnel in place while tamping however, if you grind too fine you will still have these issues. My advice is to dial in before you're stuck on the trail not knowing what to do, and just be patient and allow it to depressurize if this happens. The most annoying part here is that they don't say ANYTHING about this in the manual other than mentioning the automatic depressurizing valve in the water reservoir. When the device seized up, I tried opening this valve further using the distributor tool and I believe this hastened the process slightly, but it still took a long time before I could unscrew the portafilter.

SUMMARY:
Sorry this is so long but I felt it was important to mention these things. Definitely a step up from the Nanopresso and recommend purchasing this if you want a portable espresso machine, as long as you are willing to put up with the initial frustration of figuring out how to use it properly.

title: Tested 3 different travel espressos
body:
So I bought the picospresso, the outin and the flair pro 2.

The pico was my second favorite but at the end of the day it’s 95% plastic. While I am sure the plastic is food safe, etc. you’re heating plastic to like 212 degrees for a decent amount of time, I just don’t see this unit holding up long term, so I sent it back.

Assuming you can get past the plastic construction, of the 3 I tested, this came in 2nd. I pulls a pretty good shot that is pretty consistent if you pay attention to the details. You want to use freshly ground espresso, every finely ground, weigh out 18 grams and preheat the pico. If you follow these steps and you pump at a fairly consistent but slow pace you’ll get a dang good shot of espresso.

So it does make a decent espresso so that’s why I gave it 4 stars. The pump mechanism to me doesn’t seem like it’s going to last.

versus the outin, depending on what your plan for usage is, the pico makes a better shot. I ended up sending the pico and the outin back after using all three for a bit the flair was hands down the winner, but the trade off is complexity and mobility. The pico shines as far as weight and space it takes up in your bag. For some applications, assuming you can get past the heading of food safe plastic to above 200F part this might be the travel espresso machine for you. If you’re going to be away from power, ie camping etc, the outin starts to make some sense.

All in all I can’t fault the pico, it’s a great design, it’s lightweight and relatively expensive. How long it will last is hard to say, but reading through the reviews I think you can expect to use this occasionally while traveling and probably last a while. It’s very well thought out with everything fitting into the small package, Greta for traveling with limited luggage space, but I don’t see a ton of upsides besides that aspect.

title: Over-promised and under-delivered. Used it for a day and will return it. Overpriced Moka pot
body:
To give this thing a fair shake - its fine. It makes decent coffee. Nice unboxing experience. All the metal pieces are well machined and the plastic ones are high quality with tight tolerances. It is easy enough to use but maybe finicky (more on that in a moment). It fits together well and packs up great for travel.

The problem is that its in the sphere of espresso, and in particular marketed (Especially on places like YouTube) to specialty coffee enthusiast. It makes good coffee, but I struggle with the idea of calling it espresso. I know that by all technical definitions it is espresso, but it lacks a lot of the texture and taste of espresso. Over a day of messing around with it, shots consistently had a mouthfeel between an AeroPress and a moka pot. in truth i prefer the moka pot. Despite dialing in grind and distribution on my mignon silenzio shots were consistently weak compared to a gcp. There was no crema to speak of either. While the coffee was good (good coffee in= good coffee out) it did not deliver what I was after. I bought this looking for a good travel espresso machine. Its okay, and in truth if i had spend $50 less on it I might have been happy. But real human I-worked-for-this-money dollars, I would have rathered a $20 moka pot. Additionally, its small size means that while you can fit 18g into the portafilter basket, you can only barely fit that much water into it making the end of the shot constantly a mess.

This device lives in a no-mans-land between an AeroPress and Flair. Slightly richer and deeper than an AeroPress, and about halfway to a Flair. But at 3-4x the cost of an AeroPress (which I was intending it to replace), you are not getting a 3-4x closer to quality espresso.

The biggest problem here is the expectation. If it was marketed as a high quality robust premium AeroPress competitor, I could see it having a logical value. If it is marketed as a cheaper more portable espresso maker like the flair, it falls very very far short. In the end if you are looking for the second it is not worth it. If you are looking for the first it may be worth it.

---Also entirely a side note, all the silicon (and there is a lot in this thing) smells so new that the chemically smell is overwhelming and I spent a lot of time just trying to clean it off without really succeeding. id recommend the company try to air it out a bit before they sell it.

The quality looks great, packaging amazing. Basket quite decent. Tamper, dosing funnel etc. are nice.

The dosing funnel is just adequate height, but filter and collar are not quite robust enough to tap out all the grounds from my kinu grinder bin.

I recommend using a real WDT tool, rather than the included pin for declumping, prepping grounds before tamping.

[I have edited this review. Initially I had trouble with level tamping, but it turns out I was using a less than ideal surface. I used a kitchen counter with decent height and had zero issues. I also never tamped with the collar in place]

You really MUST preheat this, running VERY hot water through it, to avoid thermal loss. If you preheat it correctly, it will be probably be too hot to hold in your bare hands to pump. Its easy to burn yourself pouring water in, and handling till the cover is on.

A note on pumping: If you push the plunger all the way in while pumping, you'd better use a little torque while pumping to keep the plunger from locking itself closed position with every pump. [Update, this issue disappeared the after my first use, however pumping seemed more difficult after a couple of days, exasperatingly so, but then I have small hands, am not the youngest, and this really needs

I was able to use exact same dose and grind size (17-18g) that already works in my Gaggia Classic Pro.
The ability to control preinfusion is of course wonderful, and probably necessary.

I bought this to take on vacation, it's of course much fussier to use, but it is perfect for the purpose, and can get delicious results. [Note having used this on vacation for the last four days, my palms are sore from pumping about three of these a day, But now I have well developed pectoral muscles]

title: Traveling "Flair 58"...With A Catch.
body:
My daily (now) is the Flair 58 using the high-flow basket. However, I had the Picopresso as my first "machine," and I learned a lot from how to turn a sour shot or bad shot into a "good" shot (back then, it was amazing, but the Flair 58 ALWAYS produces an "amazing" shot so expectations have changed), recipes, and techniques.

Now the Picopresso is only used for traveling. The Picopresso with the single origin beans (ex Columbia from Aponte Village or Hulia) and a hand grinder (ex K6 hand grinder) beats all the 3rd wave cafes and 2nd wave cafes (ex. Starbucks) out there.

So the catch...I mentioned you need the right fresh and delicious single-origin beans. An "excellent" espresso hand grinder. The other is a high-flow basket (ex 51mm basket here in Amazon), and a 51mm puck screen. Also, do not forget to use the included WDT as part of your workflow.

The other missing piece is you, the end user, willing to learn, research, and improve to extract that 100%. It will be tough with the Picopresso, but very possible!

Also, this thing is tough for being all plastic. I have dropped it so many times at work and traveling. The only way it will break (the weak point is the piston) is if the end user doesn't know what they're doing, "cough"grind coarser, not finer"cough".

EDIT: Want to include. If there's no crema on your shot from the Picopresso. You're using light or medium roast beans that is over six weeks old, but the good news is. No crema is better, as the crema contains the "yuck" sourness or bitterness. However, if you insist on chasing that crema, get dark roast beans roasted on the same day (for maximum CO2) for that thick dark "Hollywood" crema. Grind finer and extraction time comes into play as well. Grind when you're pulling a shot, do not buy ground coffee, as ground coffee gets stale within 30 minutes.

title: Nice gadget, but no espresso yet
body:
I'm impressed, but didn't manage to make an espresso with crema, so not ready to give a 5/5 yet.
I'll keep trying and update this if I manage to do it.

FEELS PREMIUM
I own a lots of gadgets and some are more expensive than this one. This one FEELS premium among them. It's weighty, has thick metal parts (not just metal finish), thick plastic, with pleasant rubberized exterior (for grip) and such. Carrying case feels similar to those you might get for premium gadgets, but somehow better. It could be because it's a little thicker, a little softer (doesn't feel like plastic), and has big zipper, which adds character. Even the box feels expensive as this has this velvety finish. When unpacking I often get disappointed at a feel of pricy things. This wasn't one of those times.

The few cosmetic things I would improve to perfect the feel of this kit are
- Round edges on the scoop. MAYBE make it a bit thicker. Sharp edges make it look cheap within the set.
- Custom brush to fit the kit. Current one feels generic (just like the one I got with every bear trimmer). It has no good place and rattles inside.
- Custom Distributor tool. Again would be nice if it didn't rattle inside.

My only concern for the quality of this thing is the pump. I feel like it is mostly plastic (based on how it presses), which could mean short lifespan of the gadget.

COMPACT
The whole kit barely takes up any space. If you manage to get it working right (I didn't yet), you get espressos anywhere out of a kit that fits in 1 hand. It's impressive.

COFFEE GRINDER needed
This thing is virtually worthless without correctly ground beans. This means you need an adjustable coffee grinder or access to coffee that's ground the right way. According to manual if the coffee is ground too fine you'll have blockages resulting in just strong coffee without crema (I experienced this). If it's too coarse it passes through too easily and doesn't get infused too well and obviously also no crema. It might be obvious to experts, but it wasn't to me.

For what it's worth I liked the strong coffee, but it would be a stretch calling what I made an espresso. It could be might be my lack of experience with coffee brewing.

DIFFICULT TO WASH
There are 2 parts which are impossible to fully dry. Manual suggests leaving everything to dry for 2 hours, but I opened one of the pieces up and saw droplets inside.

The cup/pump thing is the first part. You can empty the liquids, but there's always some left over inside the pumping mechanism.

The second part is this little piece that cannels water into a coffee grounds, as it consists of a metal plate and a rubber cap that attaches over that plate. The rubber is removable, but doing it after each use means streching/wearing out the rubber.

Moisture is a concern, because in storage this device is basically a capsule with metalic components. Add moisture to that and you have perfect conditions for rust to form.

I'll update this review after I get a different coffee grinder (or learn a better technique for brewing), but for now .

title: A lot of hard work for a lukewarm espresso
body:
The Picopresso is not suited for hiking. You'll need boiling water for a lukewarm cup, even after pre-heating the cup and the machine. And you will need a very-fine grind.
We use an organic, all-arabica, super fine grind and the taste is deeper than with a mocha pot. It's a little unnerving though to use boiling water on the grind and trust that it won't burn it and come out bitter - it does if we pack the grind just a bit.
The concertina packing is a little daunting at first but you get used to it (which is that you stop packing all the bits unless you're travelling).
We manage to get a little crema but it is really hard work to extract and as it doesn't come out hot, it is a shortly enjoyed experience. The pump has squeaked ever since we got it. We found that the double-shot basket was using way too much grind for the amount to drink, and not necessarily that much stronger than the single-cup basket that we replaced it with (we didn't find one sold by Wacaco).
For £40 more, you could get a counter-top espresso machine. I'm still using my Picopresso and I can take it away on holiday if camping or renting, which is more pleasurable that having to make do with an oversized French press. And the physical effort is somewhat curbing my caffeine intake, which is not a bad thing. But in truth, I more readily walk around the block for an expensive cup on the high street.
Something we didn't realise immediately, the case and the picopresso are not symmetrical - the zip is fairly cheap and will reopen if you put it in the wrong way.

title: Design flaws
body:
I spent several hours today dialing in the grind for my light roast in the Picopresso and the product is impressive in many respects. There are however notable flaws.

First, the difficulty of using light roast in this unit is well established (on yt) but should be prominent in the official marketing. Anyone hoping to have a good first day with the Picopresso should probably start with a dark roast. Second--I knew it would get hot but wow, I could barely hang on to the thing. Mine now has a silicon mat strapped to it with elastics which I hope will help. Not pretty. I see they sell a cover but it looks to me like it would trap moisture. Third--the tamper does not fit the basket perfectly and it leaves me with a small (~0.5mm) ring of untamped coffee. It seems odd to me that they would not fit better considering that they both came from the same manufacturer. The basket really stands out as the weakest part of the unit. It looks like it's meant to be replaced (I have already ordered the IMS).

The build quality is otherwise impressive and I am optimistic that once I spend the time and money to fix these problems I will enjoy the Picopresso.

Edit: after three days it started leaking on to the counter during preheat and the pump lost all pressure. Returned for refund as I doubt even a replacement would last more than a couple of months of regular use.

One more design flaw I forgot to mention before is the threads on the reservoir--they are finicky, prone to cross-threading, and you will be burning your hands with boiling water if you try to assemble quickly.

title: Broke after third use - Not built to last

This brewer is clearly not intended for long-term durability, which is unfortunate because that there are so few alternatives in the category. Given the $130 price point, this is very overpriced; the quality is just not there. If you don't care about durability, and you just want something portable then you may be happy with this. In my opinion, this is way too much money for something that is likely to break on you. Look elsewhere if you want a quality product.

Pros:
- Very easy to use if you already know how to dial in espresso
- Extremely compact
- Makes solid espresso
- Comes with everything you need, including tamper and distribution tool

Cons
- Cheap construction; not built to last and lacking in quality control
- Overpriced for what it does
- Pump can be a little tiresome
- Cleanup is a bit of chore

body:
Il prodotto che ho ricevuto tramite il Programma Recensori Vine è conforme alla descrizione del produttore. Anche la foto è fedele e perfettamente corrispondente all’articolo.

Si tratta di una sorta di macchina espresso portatile che dovrebbe servire per poter gustare un buon espresso in qualsiasi momento e luogo. Il packaging è veramente curato e così l'articolo; la qualità costruttiva è ai massimi livelli, è sicuramente un oggetto che, se regalato, vi farà fare una bellissima figura.

Purtroppo però, all'atto pratico, mi ha lasciata un po' perplessa; in tutta onestà l'ho trovato un oggetto abbastanza inutile o perlomeno non all'altezza del prezzo di vendita. 

Queste le considerazioni:

- La macchina funziona con acqua bollente; questo vuol dire che insieme dobbiamo avere con noi anche un thermos che la contiene. 

- Nella descrizione c'è scritto: " il caffè premacinato commerciale non funzionerà bene per estrarre un buon espresso con crema. L'uso di caffè in grani fresco è altamente raccomandato per ottenere il miglior risultato." Questo vuol dire che dobbiamo anche preoccuparci di macinare i grani di caffè; oltre al thermos dobbiamo quindi avere con noi anche un macinacaffè?

- Ho provato con vari tipi di caffè macinato ma il risultato è stato un caffè stile moka, niente a che vedere con un espresso; sicuramente la colpa sarà mia per non essere riuscita a trovare la grana perfetta ma sinceramente non pensavo che per fare un caffè al volo servisse una laurea in CAFFEOLOGIA!

Concludendo:

a meno che non vogliate fare un regalo all'amico/a amante delle cose belle anche se inutili ... lasciate perdere. Un bar per prendere un caffè al volo si trova sempre e in casi estremi c'è sempre il buon vecchio thermos pieno di caffè della moka preparato a casa!

title: Podrás preparar un café expreso en cualquier parte, pero es algo engorrosa de usar.
body:
Comenzamos!

Estamos ante una pequeña cafetera para prepararnos como su nombre indica un café expreso, en este caso es un concepto diferente ya que no necesitaremos ni electricidad para enchufarla a la red, ni calentarla ya bien sea con fogones o vitrocerámicas, esto es simple y llanamente para “llevar” o portátil.

La presentación es correcta ya que es un producto premium, pero en este apartado hay un pequeño problema y aunque no lo podemos achacar directamente al fabricante, así es como vendrá, sin ningún tipo de protección, directamente en la caja del producto y con la pegatina de envio pegada sobre esta, si bien lo que es la caja, lleva una funda de cartón a modo de presentación general y es donde viene esta pegada, le restará encanto.

Continuando con la presentación, en la funda anteriormente dicha podemos observar en la cara principal (una vez hemos quitado la molesta pegatina), una fotografía de la cafetera siendo usada, el nombre de la marca del fabricante y del producto. En la parte de atrás tenemos unas breves instrucciones, las características del producto y por último otra foto del mismo. Una vez retiramos esto, tenemos una caja dura con el nombre y el logotipo de la marca.

Para abrirla solamente tenemos que retirar la tapa y encontraremos de manera colocada, nuestra cafetera, varios de sus accesorios, como son, el prensador para el café molido que usaremos más adelante, un adaptador para la cesta del filtro a modo de aro metálico, una pequeña herramienta (más bien es una aguja), un sobre con el manual de instrucciones de la cafetera, en varios idiomas entre ellos el castellano, dos pegatinas, la tarjeta de garantía y por último un estuche semirrígido. Realmente los accesorios se pueden meter dentro de la picopresso y así tenerlo todo recogido en un mismo lugar, para poder además llevarla a cualquier parte y que no nos falte nada. Cabe destacar que dentro de la misma también encontraremos, dentro del deposito de agua un pequeño cepillo y en la zona baja o filtro, una cuchara.

¿Pero es fácil de usar?

Pues sinceramente si, lo único que cuando lees el manual de instrucciones y aunque tengamos ilustraciones para ello, hay quizás demasiados pasos que nos pueden crear algo de confusión la primera vez que la vamos a usar. Por otra parte cabe destacar que necesitaremos agua hirviendo o almenos caliente y esto no lo proporciona nuestra picopresso.

Conclusión: Un producto premium y muy curioso, la idea es poder hacer un café en cualquier parte, sin necesidad de tener electricidad, gas o fuego y ocupando el menor espacio posible, ya que esta cafetera es francamente pequeña, pero es que además tiene unos materiales premium y esta cuidada al detalle, desde su presentación hasta incluso el manual de instrucciones. Por otra parte no todo va a ser bueno y le veo más sombras que luces, si bien la idea y el formato prometen mucho, se quedan en eso, una mera promesa, si que es cierto que te puedes preparar un café (corto, lo que viene a ser un expreso de toda la vida) debido a su capacidad en el depósito del agua (80ml.) y su cesta en la zona del filtro para 18g de café molido, pero como describo es mas un engorro que otra cosa, nos puede sacar de un apuro, pero necesitamos agua hirviendo, o almenos lo suficientemente caliente para que el café salga bien, esto en casa no es un problema, pero fuera en plan acampada, la tendremos que llevar en un buen termo, que aguante bien el agua a una temperatura adecuada o usar fuego, gas o electricidad lo que entonces deja el producto en algo un poco prescindible o más bien un “gadget” inservible, porque para eso ponemos la típica cafetera moka y además podemos preparar más de una taza si no estamos solos. Por lo tanto, lo considero de poca utilidad y más un engorro que una ayuda. Y aunque el conjunto cumple su cometido, y el café sale en unas condiciones bastante óptimas yo no la recomiendo.

title: Ausbaufähiger Kaffeebereiter
body:
Als mobiler Begleiter bei Ausflügen etc. bringt die kleine handliche Espressomaschine eigentlich beste Voraussetzungen für einen Top Kaffeegenuss fern der heimischen Siebträgermaschine mit .
Sie ist insgesamt sehr hochwertig und präzise verarbeitet. Für Design, Material und Verarbeitung kann man gut 5 Sterne vergeben und diese rechtfertigen auch die Preiskategorie der handlichen Maschine.
Für die Anwendung, um dann wirklich einen guten Espresso aus der Maschine zu zaubern, braucht es schon etwas Zeit, Geduld, diverse Kaffeesorten UND weiteres Equipment: Neben Wasserkocher und co. auch eine ultrafein mahlende Kaffeemühle, sowie anfangs auch eine Gramm-Waage für die Füllmenge.
Nach vielen (wirklich sehr vielen) Versuchen mittels Variationen in Mahlgrad, Bohnensorte, Füllmenge etc. gelang tatsächlich ein geschmacklich gut trinkbarer (doppelter) Espresso, der allerdings nicht heiß genug in der Tasse ankommt (trotz Vorwärmen aller beteiligten Utensilien).  
Die Idee dieser portablen Espressomaschine ist natürlich im ersten Moment wirklich verlockend, auch die Wertigkeit des Produkts und die Funktionsweise darf man hier nicht schlecht reden.
Jedoch muss man sich bewusst sein, dass es keine handliche „Pulver rein und fertig“ Maschine ist, sondern man im halb Gramm-Bereich, mit direkt vor Ort frisch gemahlener Bohne, frisch aufgekochtem Wasser und heißer Espresso-Porzellantasse die Herstellung zelebriert, um dann hoffentlich seinen Espresso genießen zu können.
Was für uns auf unseren Touren als gute Alternative zum klassischen Espressokocher gedacht war, läuft mit der Hand-Press-Maschine aber eher auf eine verliebte Spielerei hinaus.
Da wir eher zu den „faulen“ Espressokochern gehören reicht uns, für den Espresso/Kaffeegenuss am Berg, ein günstiger Espressokocher für den Gasherd bzw. den Kartuschenbrenner.  
Wer aber ohnehin unter obigen Randbedingungen seinen Spaß daran hat, einen Espresso auch mal in alternativer Pump-Weise herzustellen, dem ist die kleine Picopresso ans Herz zu legen.

title: Tutto stile
body:
Macchinetta del caffè espresso portatile, già il nome è esplicativo.
Con questo accessorio è possibile gustarsi un espresso fatto a regola d'arte in qualunque luogo (anche in cima a una montagna).
Una precisazione: la macchinetta fa effettivamente il caffè espresso (nulla a che vedere con quello solubile, americano o della moka), ma non scalda l'acqua; questo vuol dire che bisogna portarsi un termos con acqua bollente o un sistema per bollirla (fornello e pentolino).
Vista in quest'ottica diventa abbastanza ingombrante, pesante e laborioso farai il caffè.
Direi che si presta solo a chi veramente non può fare a meno del caffè espresso.
Altra piccola nota: la procedura per fare il caffè è abbastanza laboriosa, bisogna scaldare la macchinetta caricando acqua bollente e facendola erogare tramite la pompetta, poi svuotarla, mettere il caffè, ricaricare l'acqua e finalmente fare il caffè.
Alla fine dei conti è un oggetto più scenico che pratico, oltretutto costa 150€, mi sembra decisamente eccessivo.

title: Es todo un lujo... pero cuánto de práctico?
body:
Antes de nada usé un molinillo de café para encontrar la molienda perfecta e intentar sacar el máximo provecho a esta pequeña cafetera que a priori se presenta como una de las mejores cafeteras portátiles y lo demuestra con una facilidad pasmosa.

En este caso, los mejores resultados para preparar un buen café espresso pasa por conseguir un gránulo muy fino, es decir, cuando frotas el café entre los dedos y te los deja  manchados...ese es su punto ideal.

En este sentido, el café que prepara esta genialidad es francamente bueno, hay que reconocerlo, me sorprende que algo tan extraordinariamente pequeño tenga la  capacidad de conseguir un café de ese nivel. El gran escollo, para mí, es que su precio  alcanza una cota muy alta para las limitadas prestaciones que encontramos en esta cafetera. Sigue un protocolo sencillo aunque para llegar a hacer un café con una delicada crema se aleja de la simplicidad con la que trabaja, la molienda debe tener un determinado granulado muy fino, no he probado con los cafés que ya vienen molidos y no podría deciros si se consigue el mismo efecto.

¿Merece la pena su compra? No es  precisamente un producto barato teniendo en cuenta que disponemos de una cubeta para un sólo café. Además, para llegar a conseguir un brebaje ideal, la temperatura del agua debe mantenerse alta y si consideramos un uso portátil tenemos que contar además con un termo que lamentablemente no va a mantener la temperatura idónea para llegar a disfrutar de todas las cualidades de un buen café. Si la idea pasa por un uso en casa, en mi opinión, disponemos de otras opciones más razonables y cómodas, en todos los sentidos, en este caso no le veo mucha trayectoria pero para gustos colores.

Su presentación es uno de sus mayores atractivos, si estás pensando en hacer un regalo ya te adelanto que es una verdadera preciosidad y todo un lujo para aquellos, que como yo, nos volvemos sibaritas a la hora de disfrutar de un buen café.

Estoy seguro que dejará impresionados a muchos en cuanto a su calidad, resultado de un buen trabajo, y por el aroma y sabor que desprende porque lo cierto es que prepara un buen café expreso.

title: Works great, easy to clean, a bit pricey
body:
I have an espresso addiction, but also travel frequently, so that meant I needed a portable way to brew my favorite espresso while on the road. This thing works great for that, just need hot water. Before purchasing I read a few reviews that said the process of making espresso in it was tedious, and that it was hard to clean. I found neither of those to be the case. Making espresso in it requires almost the same steps as making espresso in a proper machine, the only additional step that I can think of is the pre-heating of this one, and boiling your own water. Clean up, despite reviews to the contrary is super easy, knock out the puck, rinse everything well with hot water, and allow to dry, its that simple!! Also, the pumping action is not hard at all, even with my arthritis, I am able to use my palms to pump the plunger.

The only reason I wrote this review is because I was almost discouraged by the reviews that stated those things, I am glad I took a chance and tried this espresso maker out, it works great! I do feel that the price is a bit high, especially when you can get an Outin Nano, which will make the espresso for you with no pumping required (I also have one of those for the office, just needed this unit for ultra portability) for only slightly more, though it only does single shots without purchasing the separate basket plus. Though I understand this is a very niche market, and that is the reason for the pricing, like all niche items.

title: Really works!
body: Amazingly, this little device is capable of producing beautiful espresso. However, it is quite a hassle to use. I cannot imagine many people bothering with it very often. You need a grinder capable of producing extra-fine ground coffee (such a grinder will probably cost you more than this Picopresso costs). You will need to weigh the amount of coffee to get it just right (too tight, and the Picopresso is not capable of pumping water through it; too loose, and you get a nasty thin espresso). You have to pre-heat the Picopresso with boiling water, which is hard to do without getting hot water on your hands. Then when you pump the espresso, the Picopresso gets uncomfortably hot to hold. Finally, you have to wash and dry everything. Honestly, how many people are routinely going to do all this? Maybe the Picopresso is more of a novelty item. But if you are prepared to put in the effort, the Picopresso really works. So overall, my recommendation is that if you are a determined sort of coffee buff, you will love the Picopresso - it produces fantastic espresso.

body:

But cleaning it properly requires it to be disassembled, which is easy enough, but there are probably 12 different pieces. All washers, filters, rings, etc. It's like I'm disassembling a rifle. Or building a Lego set.

So the time you save making the espresso at your desk, you're just spending cleaning the thing. But if that doesn't bother you, it's pretty good.

title: Fantastic espresso maker for the price
body: I use this as my daily espresso maker at home because actual espresso machines are too expensive and take up too much counter space. I am super impressed with the quality of espresso shot it can pull. It took me a couple tries to nail down the best grind size and grams of coffee, but now I get great-tasting espresso with a nice layer of crema every time. There are two things though that prevent me from giving this 5 stars. One is how hot it gets when you're pumping it. It gets so hot I can't hold it with my bare hands and I have to wrap it in a towel. Personally, I would trade some of the compactness for slightly better insulation and a safer temperature. The other concern is how difficult it is to clean. It's difficult to fully get all of the water out of the chamber after using it and rinsing it out. I set it out on the counter to dry until the next morning but if I were putting it away immediately I would worry about possible mold/mildew buildup. But those are very minor complaints and I would still highly recommend this little gadget. It's hands-down the best portable espresso maker I've ever tried.

I have nice Alex Duetto E61 paired with a Niche Zero grinder at home and have been looking for something to use at work and found this. For work we have a hot water kettle and I have a Bartza Virtuoso that I have been using for pour overs and French Press, but have been longing for my Espresso in the afternoon, now I can have it! You will need a capable grinder, hot water, a scale and a bit of time. Your efforts will be rewarded with quality shot and a bit of clean up to do, but it will be well worth the time and effort. The only place this falls a bit short is that after you are done with making your shot the clean up take a little effort, in particular the rubber seal on the shower screen takes a little fidgeting with to get it back on after it is removed for cleaning.

title: A great little espresso maker, but needs a reality check before purchase.
body:
So I bought this thing because I fell in love with the idea of making espresso outside, in nature!

However, I wish I just got a thermos or an Aeropress.

Using this espresso maker involves a lot of steps, and needs a good amount of clear space.
there is the tamper, the tamper ring, the porta filter, the showerscreen, the distrubution, you'll need hot water, something to clean it after, your beans or grinds....

I'd recommend that you carry a piece of cloth to put everything on, and be careful so you don't drop it on the dirty ground.

after all that, you need to preheat the picopress, prepare your puck and what not. this process is not hard on a table or near a sink, although there can be spills, but in nature or a park, it's very annoying.

After your shot, you need to figure out where to put the thing, and after you're done, you need to clean it, which involves rinsing every part (with cold water) and then drying it, unless yu want to put it back together moist (Not sure if that's a good idea or not)

As you see, it's just... to involved, so ask yourself, do you really need Espresso THAT bad? If this brings you joy then sure, but a pourover or aeropress is so much neater and easier.

also I tried using a thermos and even after 30m-1h of walking, the water was near 85c which with pre-heating, gave me very mediocre lukewarm Espresso (although it was super windy)

additionally, I made the mistake of pushing the pump too hard as I felt resistance, and this thing leaked all over me, I had to walk back home covered in Espresso. II also think I didn't tighten the group head enough.

I'd remove half a star because the bottom shower screen cover fell during brewing once and it caused a mess.

I also really encourage a thorough clean as my espresso smelled and tasted like chemicals after just rinsing it a bit.

So consider this:
- You can pretty much only use darker roasts or medium-dark roasts for decent espresso
- You highly benefit from boiling water, a Thermos CAN work, but it'll be a pain and not super enjoyable IMO.
- All the cleaning and prep involved, you absolutely need a proper table

so this is more for proper camping, where you can use a butane kettle, or for travelling and making espresso at a hotel or work or someone's house. I'd not recommend this for casual coffee.

I still gave it 5 stars because technically, It was me getting caught up in the idea of making espresso outside without doing a reality check, and it seems like a very well-built product!

Also, since this is not a pressurized basket (I wish they let you choose!) you need a portable hand grinder, I just ground my coffee at home since I was only taking a 1h walk.

With the Wacaco Picopresso I found the perfect solution - a great entry point into the world of home espresso, while also becoming a perfect travel item, along with my Aeropress and grinder. Now it's incredibly fun to know that every coffee drink in the world is possible and accessible, which is honestly a great feeling that I've been chasing for years.

Als ich gesehen habe, dass es die Presse jetzt mit vollwertigem Siebträger system gibt habe ich zwar noch etwas gezögert aber mir dann doch schlussendlich gekauft. Ich wurde nicht enttäuscht.

Beide Pumpen haben ihre Berechtigung und vor und Nachteile im relativen Vergleich.
Die Nanopresso ist etwas leichter, hat wie ich finde das etwas bessere Packmaß obwohl länger ist sie etwas schmaler und lässt sich im Rucksack prima irgendwo zwischenquetschen.
Sie verzeiht auch wenn nicht der richtige Mahlgrad getroffen wurde, es kommt dennoch ein annehmbares Getränk heraus. Weiterhin positiv hervorzuheben ist die im Wassertank enthaltene Tasse.
Allerdings ist die Pumpe komplett aus Plastik und erzeugt den Espresso über eine Düse unterhalb des plastik siebes.

Die Picopresso fühlt sich wie ein Premium Produkt an. Bei öffnen der Verpackung habe ich mich bereits über das wertige Design gefreut.
Die Pumpe kommt mit viel Zubehör...einen Becher muss man jedoch selbst mitbringen.
Es fühlt sich alles sehr wertig an und die Teile haben eine hervorragende Qualität, hier ist ein vollwertiger Bodenloser Siebträger verbaut.
Bei der Bohnenmenge und dem Mahlgrad muss man genau arbeiten bekommt dafür als Gegenleistung aber einen hervorragenden Espresso.
Auch ist das vorheizen des Systems wichtig.
Was mir nicht so gut gefällt ist das Gewinde für den Deckel des Wasserreservoir, dieses lässt sich nicht so leichtgängig wie bei der nano aufschrauben. Bei vollem Reservoir kann da auch Mal ein Tropfen vorbei schwappen.

title: Great espresso but some things to consider
body:
Exactly as advertised, very high quality manufacture, great espresso. Some things to consider:

1. there are a LOT of parts that will be hard to remember how to assemble at first. It would be nice to have a printed blow-out illustration of assembly order on the inside of the holding case. A bit fussy to assemble/disassemble/clean.
2. you have to twist the edge of the pump plunger to get it to pop out. The edge is very thin and made of slippery material. If this were ridged it would make twisting it much easier.
3. if you have a home espresso maker / grinder you will find the Picospresso needs an even finer grind, sometimes labeled as "Turkish coffee". You really MUST have a quality burr grinder to get this fine. I pre-grind with my home grinder when I'm on a trip so this is not a problem but you may need to invest in their hand grinder, which I did not try.
4. heavier in the hand than you might expect -- fastidious backpackers may complain but for my travel via car/airplane it is not an issue. On the other hand it is because it seems very well made and of high quality metal and silicone.
5. The carrying case is very nice but tight and I worry that the zippers might not be up to the task for the lifetime of the product, even though they are made of sturdy stainless steel -- not plastic ones.
6. I have heard the pump action described as "a bit stiff" but I found it quite smooth and easy to use. It is two handed but unless you have strongly arthritic hands you should have not problem with it.
7. A real portafilter basket, nice. Does NOT use pods -- ugh!
8. obviously you will need a source of boiling water. If your hotel only has electric outlets and no microwave, you may need a portable hot water maker.
9. perhaps obviously it does not steam milk.

I love the Picospresso and am a picky espresso drinker. This will make my travel (6-8 weeks per year) so much more enjoyable. Good espresso on the road is spotty at best and now I probably won't bother looking.

UPDATE:
I've now used this one a few trips an it does make incredible espresso! However I find two problems.
1. It is like solving a puzzle each time I re-assemble it. They designed for compactness but sacrificed in the somewhat ridiculous complexity of packing it back up.
2. When I traveled with another espresso lover I found that pulling the second shot will lock up the device. The portafilter becomes extremely hard to push water through AND it was impossible to unscrew after the (difficult) second shot. I had to wrap it in a plastic bag (it will leak) and pack it with grounds still in the device - then disassemble and clean at the next opportunity. From now on I'll wash the bottom section, the one with the portafilter, in COLD water before trying to pull the second shot. This should help with both problems like it does in my home machine.

UPDATE 2:
Some design suggestions after extended trip usage:
1. The plastic lid on top contains the hot water. It has no grippy texture like the portafilter tightener. Be CAREFUL, if this is not on TIGHT you'll get boiling hot water dribbling on your hands when you pump. It would be great if this lid had a grip texture. Same for the screw-out pump handle locking mechanism - it is very thin and slippery when wet, when locking it down for storage.
2. The pump is a bit hard to use - you have to squat or contort to cover some cup or glass receptacle and compress using your chest muscles, not your hand gripping muscles - all without splattering hot coffee everywhere. I eventually found a plastic insulated cup the fit tightish around the bottom of the picospresso. This allows me to hold it in a way where I use my gripping muscles. The bottom has a flat rubber cover, why not make an accessory rubber cup-sized cover to solve this problem?

These tweaks would make it easier and safer to use and less messy.

Still the espresso if awesome in the extreme so worth the fussiness.

title: Non è un prodotto per tutti.
body:

Bisogna acquisire una certa manualità e il prodotto è molto sensibile al grado di macinature che deve essere molto fine. Per esempio ho dovuto utilizzare un macina caffè professionale (nel video 1Zpresso JX-PRO costo 160 euro) regolato su 14 click. Serve un caffe tostato in chicchi di qualità (nel video CAFES GULIUS DESDE 1928 costo 18 euro al kg) nel mio caso l’ottimale è 19grammi. Esce un caffè doppio ristretto cremoso come da video. Se volete un caffè normale dovete mettere metà dose di macinato, però con 8g scende un caffè normale come da moka. Come da foto QUESTO ARTICOLO NON E’ IDONEO AL RESO quindi pensateci bene prima di acquistarlo. Mi ha contattato il venditore dicendo che loro accettano il reso e di sentire Amazon per verificare. Non ho intenzione di restituire il prodotto quindi non ho approfondito la cosa.
PRO:

Materiali di qualità,

Venditore gentile e disponibile a fornire indicazioni per utilizzare il prodotto al meglio
CONTRO:
Richiede esperienza, manualità e tempo per fare un buon espresso.
Il costo è troppo elevato (con 150 euro si compera una macchina espresso che fa tutto lei),
Richiede una macinatura di estrema precisione che si ottiene solo macinando chicchi con strumenti professionali,

title: Simply brilliant
body:
I bought this for my partner and I together with a 1zspresso Q series hand grinder for an interstate trip. We have a good espresso machine and burr grinder at home and really miss a decent coffee at the start and end of each day when we can’t lug our equipment with us.

When combined with the 1espresso grinder and good beans, this device produces an extraordinarily good espresso coffee: as good as any you would get in a cafe, and better than most of them on fact. It is tiny and weighs less than 1kg when combined with the grinder (which is heavier).

Ignore those who complain about the number of parts. This is dead easy and quick to use, and just like drinking coffee, using it will become second nature after a couple of attempts. It is also extremely easy to clean (it just rinses off). It has no disposal filters or parts (unlike the Aeropress). My only proviso is that the pump requires a firm squeeze which may challenge people who are elderly or afflicted with arthritis.

Make sure you invest in a good quality, adjustable grinder (at least A$100, ours was $150 and well worth it) and take the trouble to dial in the correct grind for best results. Don’t plan on purchasing pre-ground coffee. The grind won’t be the right size to get good results and it won’t be fresh.

This is ideal for campers, travellers, and those who just don’t want to wake their household with the noise of machines first thing in the morning. I can’t recommend it highly enough.

La mouture était tros grosse mais j'ai poursuivi l'expérience.
Après avoir ébouillanté le corps de la PicoPresso et tout son système, j'ai réalisé mon premier expresso en suivant une excellente démonstration vue sur Youtube.

Une réalisation aisée, la mouture n'était pas assez fine, mais un excellent expresso en tasse.

Après, il faut nettoyer et sécher les composants : L'ensemble se compose tout de même de 10 éléments (13
en incluant la petite coupe de mesure, la mini brosse et la tige pour homogénéiser la mouture)

Conclusion : un excellent produit, fourni avec un étui rigide pour le ransport qui peut absolument tout contenir en un seul bloc, y compris les accessoires externes

title: Sublime shot. Niche. Brilliant. Not stand alone and many parts.
body:
This machine is awesome! Totally blown away. I mentioned in the catch line that it isn’t stand alone. Why?

Well-Opinion commentary here:
To do this correctly you will need a scale, a great mill, and (obviously) a kettle. Whole beans-dark roast.

So, that cuts down on portability for me. Although, of itself, the machine is small and portable.

What else? So…

There are MANY parts. All well machined and finished. Perfectly so, in fact. But, all the same, there are many parts that all interrelate. If my littles were to find this, I can see it losing some vital parts quickly, such as the distribution tool, the funnel ring, or any of the protective rubber caps. Even the tamper. All of the parts interrelate, as I mentioned. You could use non proprietary tools to get the job done, but the supplied ones were designed to fit.

Why did I buy this?

I bought this to keep at home in the kitchen for me time/self-care time/art of making a good shot totally manually (along with all my other ways to make coffee in small batches). I bought this as a person who has reduced caffeine intake to the bare minimum of enjoying the making of/brewing of/taste over quantity experiences.

I won’t be making me and the missus each a shot to have at the same time. I won’t be using it more than two times in one setting. It’s just to make for me because anything else would be impractical from a time perspective.

Why? It takes a while to get it working. Prep. Timing. Pre-warming. Clean up.

I bought this for the ritual of making a double shot with great crema. A task that it performs perfectly.

The machine does it beautifully. I can’t believe the thought that went into this design and the care with which it is produced. First rate.

If you are thinking you are trotting off on the PCT with this and will have great espresso every morning…doable. Maybe. Brave. Cleanup will be…no. Wait. You could do it. It’s durable. Cleanable. Mostly completely breaks down (except for pump internals). Would just need to have some extra components. But would you? I think Illy would work…the grounds are fine enough. Recommend experimenting a bit. You could maybe get away without the grinder and scale.

But for me. 7 minutes of prep (going slow-weighing/grinding). 3-4 minutes of action during brewing (pour, prime, empty, fill, pre-extract, extract), and 10 minutes of cleanup for a total of 20 minutes-TOTALLY WORTH IT! Just not on the road or trail (surely, this says more about me than the picopresso).

Love this machine. Yes, it performs and feels just like what I expected for the cost. The manufacturer didn’t cut corners. Use premium, well roasted whole beans. Grind them ultra fine (don’t go as far as Turkish coffee fine, though). Weigh it out. Use filtered water. Pump at the right interval and YOU WIN.

title: For the coffee nerd not for the forest
body:
I bought this to be an espresso maker to take on vacations. The plan was to use in hotel room. If I was reviewing purely for “ Is this a good coffee maker on the go?” I would have given A more harsh review.

This machine is a coffee Nerd’s Dream. If you love fiddling with your manual espresso machine, and you just want another toy, then this machine is great. However, if you want something that you can pull out at a campsite dump in some coffee and say “close enough” I recommend you look at the nanopresso. If you want pods, then look at the minipresso.

With that out-of-the-way, I absolutely love the design of this machine It is way more substantial than the nano. The parts are made out of metal. All the parts feel so great in your hand, especially compared to the plastic versions (nano)

I would say I am wannabe barista. I love making coffee, but I’m not an expert at dialling it in. I had some trial and error with this device.
The grind size (Go as small as possible) And temperature control (You need water off the boil) are extremely important if these things are not perfect, you will get an under extracted coffee. This is why I say if you are going to play around at home for a couple hours it’s great but if you are on vacation or at a campsite and you don’t have a scale and a grinder with you, I don’t think you’ll be satisfied with the result.

One thing to know is that the nano has a pressure device built inside of it that will make sure you get to proper pressure even if your grind size is not perfect. That is not the case with this machine.

Ultimately, even though I am Giving this a five star review I am going to return this device because it doesn’t meet the need that I bought it for.

Truth be told, I bought the nano first and was blown away by the shot. I thought I would try this one because the nano only comes with a single shot Porta filter. Well, you could make two shots with the nano, temperature control is a bit difficult so by the time you make your second shot, your coffee will likely be cold.
I am investigating the nano Barista kit.

title: Semplicemente perfetta!!!
body:
Da appassionato di caffè e possessore di diverse semi automatiche per caffè in grani, ho comprato questa meraviglia più per curiosità che per necessità...
Me ne sono innamorato al primo giorno ( oggi), la semplicità di utilizzo è disarmante, al primo tentativo un caffè veramente notevole, anche se leggo recensioni che affermano il contrario... non è vero che è soltanto una cosa bella da regalare... o che serve un macinino professionale ( io ne utilizzo uno manuale pagato meno di 10 € ), basta soltanto avere l'accortezza di usare una macinatura adeguata, stringere la macina (in ceramica oltretutto) in modo da avere una polvere fine, il resto è "poesia".
Vedere il caffè scendere fluttuando dal filtro senza fondo alle semplice pressione (veramente leggera) delle dita sulla leva, già ne ripaga la spesa... senza parlare del sapore corposo che restituisce paragonabile a macchine di ben altro valore e spessore. Non voglio scomodare la Pavoni... ma sicuramente ben superiore alla maggior parte delle macchine a capsule in commercio e non solo...
Restituisce un gradevole sapore fruttato nel caso della miscela arabica o più deciso se invece si predilige una miscela robusta, che le capsule si possono solo sognare.
Tutto questo è dovuto non soltanto al notevole lavoro di questa meraviglia sapientemente studiato dalla Wacaco, ma anche al fatto che appena macinato il caffè risulta indiscutibilmente di un altro pianeta.
È una macchina, visto il minimo ingombro, che si presta all'uso esterno, tenda, montagna, lago, mare... ma io ho già studiato un metodo per tenerla fissa in cucina... perché oltre a fare un ottimo caffè ha un aspetto accattivante e vagamente futuristico, che sarebbe deleterio tenere chiusa nella sua custodia, anche se di pregevole fattura.
Che dire di più... Fare il caffè è un arte, e farlo completamente staccati dalla rete elettrica ne amplifica il valore.
È la passione che anima le emozioni, ma come in questo caso, tutto diventa più gradevole, se arrivare allo scopo è semplificato dalla qualità della materia che ci viene messa a disposizione, sia per quanto riguarda la componentistica veramente pregevole, sia per il risultato che ne consegue.

title: Impressive espresso!!!!! Buy, buy, buy if you love espresso and a morning routine
body:
After 6 months of use I'm confident that the Picopresso has to be the greatest portable espresso makers out there. I don't usually write reviews, but this product deserves one. I bought this in June for use in my camper and I now use it to make my daily coffee at home as well.

The build quality of the Picopresso is fantastic. The actual reservoir/pump and it's lid are the only plastic pieces (thankfully, otherwise it would be very hot to hold). The remainder of the pieces - dosing funnel, tamper, basket, basket holder, shower screen are all made of machined aluminum and precision engineered to fit into a tiny, beautiful, portable package. The design is impeccable and all parts fit together into a carry case not much larger than a Coke can. I use it inconjuction with a few other accessories - a scale, WDT tool, tamping mat, etc. - and carry it all, along with my coffee beans and grinder, in a small tupperware bin the size of a shoe box. The included photo shows all of the individual parts of the Picopresso (plus the scale, pot/stove, and grinder that I use when camping - not included).

I will say that the process to make an espresso shot may not be for everybody. It definitely requires a routine to boil water, grind beans, prepare your espresso puck, and brew. It takes about 10 minutes all said and done to hand grind and brew a double shot of espresso, then clean the device. With an electric burr grinder and kettle, the process is definitely simplified and does not take much longer than a traditional espresso machine. I much prefer the cleanup with this device as opposed to a french press, Aeropress, or drip coffee brewer. Only the shower screen, basket and basket holder touch the espresso and they all screw off the bottom to be rinsed easily.

Like any espresso machine, the Pico is finicky in regard to the grind size of the coffee you put into it. If you do not own (or intend to own) a capable burr grinder, then I would look at an alternative device. If your coffee is too course you will end up with dilute bean water, and if too fine, you will not be able to pump any water through the device. However, I paired mine with a simple, $150 hand grinder (VSSL Java) and have had great results. Super rich, creamy espresso shots without the need for an expensive and bulky countertop unit.

For us milk coffee drinkers, obviously a huge drawback to a device like this is that there is no milk steaming. I will usually make an americano with milk, or an iced coffee, but I sometimes bring a countertop milk frother with me if a cappucino or latte is desired - a non-issue for me, but worth considering.

Overall, I'd highly recommend this to anyone who appreciates a cafe-quality espresso and is willing to spend a few minutes each morning on their coffee rountine. I would amplify this recommendation for those who need something portable for camping, travel, at work, or living in a small space, and would also recommend the Pico to anyone who is eager to learn, experiment and have fun with the science of espresso as it's a great starting point and produces amazing coffees!

title: Non è per l'avventura, ma.....
body:
Premesso che ho già una Nanopresso da 2 anni e che la utilizzavo sia con caffè macinato sia con capsule nespresso POSSO DIRE CHE LA NANOPRESSO È UNA VERA MACCHINA PER CHI VIAGGIA. Mentre la PICOPRESSO È UNA MACCHINA PER CHI VUOLE FARSI UN CAFFÈ VERO.
Ora veniamo alla recensione della Picopresso. Innanzi tutto dovete acquistarci subito un macinino serio (quelli da 10 euro non vanno bene), io ho optato per un Normcore V2 titanium (dopo giorni di studi, video e recensioni). Per usare la Picopresso dovete prendervi del tempo, trovare un buon caffè in grani, macinarlo e quindi trovare il giusto "click" di macinatura. Io con il grinder Normcore V2 titanium ho provato dalle macinature più polverose (dagli 8 click) in su e solo al 17esimo click antiorario (solo chi ha un macinino capisce) finalmente il caffè usciva dalla picopresso senza troppa fatica: cremoso, con un bel colore e buon gusto come nei video test della Picopresso: 😂😂è stata dura, dopo oltre 100 gr di caffè buttati e almeno 2 ore di prove di caffè che non scendeva (non scoraggiatevi e andate avanti finche non avete un buon risultato) . Se vi piace il caffè con zucchero questa macchina non ha senso, si fa un caffè serio con ben 18 gr di caffè, un più che doppio caffè (al bar sono circa 14gr. Doppio) e sicuro che la caffeina ti basta anche per tutta la giornata.
L'acqua nel serbatoio permette di fare un caffè di circa 45/50gr alla tazzina per chi ama il lungo e diciamo che non è proprio lunghissimo visto che è addirittura doppio (vedremo quando mi arriva il cestello da 12gr cosa uscira e prometto un aggiornamento di recensione) loro parlano di un 35/38 gr. per la quantità "espresso".
Caffè meglio se di tostatura media ma quelli son gusti. Secondo me un Illy classico potrebbe andare ma solo in grani e non quello premacinato; io ho acquistato un caffè da una torrefazione artigianale milanese e devo dire superlativa!

Per usarla ovvio che dovete avere con voi sempre acqua calda, quindi o un bollitore in valigia o un fornelletto nello zaino; ripeto qua veramente ha più senso portarsi una NANOPRESSO nello zaino con un thermos e forse in valigia comodi una PICOPRESSO, macinino, caffè in grani, bollitore .
A chi piace bere un caffè senza zucchero la consiglio.
Non verrà mai bruciato come nella macchina da caffè elettrica visto che l'acqua la mettete voi e sicuramente non supererà mai i 90/95 gradi.

Transitioning from my durable Aeropress, i was surprised it was able to produce true espresso shots. The “dialing in” process becoming a fun experience as now i can make espresso anywhere anytime and not just in my kitchen.

title: Great for this size and price, but only if you know what you're doing
body:
This is a portable professional tool. Don't buy it if you just want an espresso machine, get a Breville Bambino instead. Don't buy it if you just want good coffee, order Cometeer. Buy this one if you like to tinker and spend half a bag of coffee to dial in a perfect shot.

The package is great:
- only slightly tapered basked, it can take 16-19 grams of coffee
- naked portafilter to watch extraction
- a little funnel and a compact tamper that can be leveled on said funnel, this is amazing
- even a tiny WDT tool to break up your clumps!
- everything can be disassembled and cleaned easily

What you absolutely need:
1. Accurate scales (I use TIMEMORE Plus)
2. Good grinder (I use Normcore V2)

Difficulty level:
1. Dark roasts: not very difficult, start with those.
2. Medium roasts: hard, you need everything to be as hot as possible and pull longer shots, I do 16 grams in, 40-42 grams out.
3. Light roasts: impossible.
Your beans must be fresh, BUT NOT TOO FRESH! At least 1 week after roast, this is important! At most 2 months.

This is my process (medium roast, pretty fine grinds):
1. Preheat the main unit pouring boiling water in it and close the lid. I don't attach the basket.
2. While it's preheating, grind coffee (I use lower dose about 16 grams) and put it into the basket.
3. Break clumps with the WDT tool and tamp over the funnel for good leveling. Can be tamped one more time without funnel if you want better compression. Don't forget to put on the puck screen. Portafilter is ready.
4. Boil the kettle one more time.
5. Pump at least a little bit of water from the unit, so hot water retained inside the pump. Then unscrew the lid and replace the water with freshly boiling.
6. Screw the portafilter in, pump 10 times and wait 20-30 seconds.
7. Pump evenly so the flow is constant until the end (40-42 grams in cup).

Don't forget that the puck screen can also be disassembled for clean up, the rubber comes off.

title: The best portable espresso device - Ever
body:
The Picopresso is absolute genius and the closest I can get to a portable device that delivers barista quality espresso. I own multiple portable espresso devices and this one leaves them all standing. I also have a pretty hefty espresso setup at home (yes I know a bit sad) and I therefore have high expectations when it comes to my daily shot or two. The Picopresso if used correctly can deliver trully exceptional results. When my home machine went in for its service a few weeks ago I used the Picopresso every day and was more than happy.

However ,there are a few howevers. You need a good quality espresso grinder for your (fresh - dark/espresso roast) beans and preferably some scales so that you use the same amount of grind every time. I use approx 15g. You can go up to 18g but thats a matter of taste. Properly tamp the beans with the funnel removed from the basket. Ideally replace the supplied basket with a 51mm full size basket (La Pavoni Europiccola baskets fit) - but only if you are as fussy as me.

Most importantly pre-heat every element before you make your coffee otherwise the results are going to be lukewarm. Avoid getting water inside the plunger. There's some great youtube videos out there.

It's a bit of a faff when you start but well worth it once you get used to it. I regularly take mine to work with my coffee pre-ground.

title: Age of coffee and grind size are key for crema
body:
Excellent extraction once you have find the correct grind size and providing your coffee is not too old. Most beans reach their top after 4 to 7 days after roasting (a bit more if really light roasted), grocery coffees have months behind them and most do not have enough CO2 left to make a nice crema. I suggest you start with a coarser grind and go finer from there to find the sweet spot. I have a Kingrinder K2 and depending on the beans, the sweet spot is between 57 and 63 clicks for me. If after 12 initial pumps you do not see anything starting coming out of the basket bottom, your grind is too fine. If it starts showing before 8 pumps, too coarse. This thing makes amazing espresso!

P.S. After buying two more for gifts (with the Kingrinder K2), I have to report that on my son's K2, only around 43-45 clicks were necessary to get crema (with the same coffee) instead of 57-63 clicks. Picopresso is very sensitive to the coarseness of grind. But once you have find the right coarseness, it gives amazing results.

title: Ever hear the saying "the journey is the reward"?
body:
Right now I'm buzzing. I'm at the early stages of figuring the Picopresso out. I'm on my fith espresso and I agree that even the tiniest adjustment can make a big difference. Such a cool lil espresso maker. I have the nanopresso and this new little fellow is in a completely different class.
The Nanopresso is much easier to use but if you are willing to put in the time and buy fresh beans the Picopresso gives better results. The one caveat is when using beans that aren't freshly roasted (I opened a "new" bag of lavazza beans and it isn't even comparable to the results from my freshly roasted local beans). I believe the Nanopresso works better if using prepackaged beans.
If you want easy espresso this isn't the machine for you but I do think once I have it all dialed in it won't be as much work.
The Nanopresso will likely remain my "travel" espresso maker since it isn't nearly as picky but we'll see if that holds true once I get the pico dialed in.
Looking through the reviews the ones who rated it poorly were not the intended consumers for this particular espresso maker. If you want to tinker a lil and become a bit more of an espresso snob...Go for it.
Also, super important...don't put your wet machine away. A week in the cupboard with a lil water in there and you will start to get some serious funk

title: Wirklich gut, ich nutze sie sogar zuhause, meine EMC schalte ich garnicht mehr eein
body:
Ich bin über die Nanopress zur Pico press gekommen.
Die nanopress war fürs Camping ganz ok.
Die Picopress nutze ich sogar zu hause, wenn ich nicht mehr als zwei Capuccini zur gleichen Zeit machen muss. Meine ECM bliebt dann aus - das spart viel Strom.

Mein Setup ist dann wie folgt:
Ich habe einen kleinen Edelstahltopf aus dem Camping-Zubehör, der funktioniert auf der Herdplatte und auch auf dem Gaskocher.
Ferner benutze ich die 1Zpresso Mühle (wirklich super).
Und für die Milch einen feuerfesten Glasbecher (ich glaube von Bodum).
Und ein kleines Thermometer, das an den Becherrand geklippt werden kann.
Und einen Stab-Milch-Aufschäumer (findet sich auch hier).

Ich setze da. 750 ml Wasser auf.
ich mahle die Bohnen. zur Abmessung habe ich mir aus Pappe einen kleineN Becher gebastelt, um immer die richtige Menge abzumessen - also ohne Waage.
Befülle das Sieb mit dem Kaffeepulver.
Dann nehme ich das erste warme bis heiße Wasser, um Tassen und picopress vorzuwärmen.
Dann nehme ich das kochende Wasser und fülle die Picopress.
Ich stelle den Michlbecher mit Milch nun in den Topf, so kann die Milch im Wasserbad auf 60-70 Grad gebracht werden.
Ich pumpe dann den Espresso.
Ich schäume die Milch mit dem Milchaufschäumer (batteriebetrieben).
fertig und genießen.

title: I am amazed and in awe of this thing
body:
Very happy with my purchase. Solid build quality. They have included everything that you will ever need to carry it as a portable espresso machine.

The coffee tastes amazing. I found it even better than professional espresso machines, and all this while you are traveling and all you have to find is hot water and ground coffee, the machine will do the rest.

I do an americano with this. The basket can take 18-20 gm of coffee grounds and you can draw a stiff double espresso shot. Add some hot water to it and you have Americano that will make you bright eyed and bushy tailed in no time!

I get me some hazelnut flavored coffee, grind it with my 1zespresso JX pro grinder and start brewing it with this machine, and within a few seconds, every soul in your 25 ft radius knows that someone is brewing some good coffee around there...

Making coffee with this thing has become a morning ritual. I love it.

Also, it does not dry out all that quickly. I could leave it out to air dry since we were in a cabin, but if one were camping with it, I imagine it would get repacked while still wet, which doesn’t seem ideal.

Overall, 100% worth the purchase. I’m probably going to spend considerable time looking for excuses to use it. Quite satisfying to get a good crema with my own hands versus an automatic machine!
